text: As I argued in the piece, I think the DNC made the donor threshold for the first debates so low that it can be gamed by disreputable people. The worry wouldn’t be that such a person would become the nominee, but could sow division.

text: The mention of “fringe candidates” doesn’t refer to candidates like Bernie & Beto who have sizable donor armies. It’s referring to no-shot candidates who will sneak into the debates under the new DNC rules

text:
Question: How many Democratic presidential candidates is going to complain that a Super PAC is getting to work on flipping Trump voters?

Answer: Zero

(More thoughts on Dems & donors from me here: https://www.politico.com/magazine/story/2019/03/20/democrats-donors-2020-debates-225884 … )
author: billscher

text: I agree that, all things being equal, better to collect the money yourself than relying on outside groups with whom you cannot coordinate. But I'm talking about a candidate trying to simply get off the ground without easy access to a small-donor base.
author: billscher

text:
For the first 2 debates, you get an invite *either* with at least 1% percent support in 3 polls (and there some parameters on which polls) *or* 65K donors, with at least 200 each coming from 20 states.

If more than 20 qualify they have a lottery to pick 20.
author: billscher

text: Thanks?
author: billscher

text: They probably would still intervene, but I think it would come with more complications
author: billscher

text: Jeb is proof that an sizable $ advantage is meaningless without g-roots support. A Super PAC for a 2nd-tier D wouldn’t guarantee victory, but could keep them competitive in the early stages against those with easier access to money, and give them a fighting chance.
author: billscher

text: Yea I’ve come full circle
author: billscher

text: Some have credibly argued the DNC could just make a rule, or interpret an existing, to deny Duke an invite. But doing that to a white supremacist would be an easy call. As we’ve seen recently, a Farrakhan-type figure accused of anti-Semitism might cause more problems.
author: billscher

text:
Democratic candidates-at least, those not named Beto and Bernie-are starting to regret idolizing the small donor

Why we shouldn’t assume the candidate with the biggest small donor is most representative of “the people,” my latest for @POLITICOMag https://www.politico.com/magazine/story/2019/03/20/democrats-donors-2020-debates-225884 …
author: billscher

text: Thank you!
author: billscher

text: Granted, it would easy for the DNC to use that rule (or make up a new one) to deal with a white supremacist. But what about a Louis Farrakhan? Or someone even more clever in dancing around the line of anti-Semitism? Recent evidence suggests that could get complicated.
author: billscher

text: Fair counter-argument! And at the end of the day, the burden is on the candidate to generate his or her own media attention that leads to above-zero poll numbers. My point is: will people who deserve a hearing get ignored because we're watching small donor metrics too closely.

text:
The DNC's new debate rules will let candidates with 65K donors, like Andrew Yang, on the stage

But has the DNC considered that a racist like David Duke could pull off the same trick?

One of the risks of idolizing the small donor. My @POLITICOMag latest:

text:
Bad idea for two reasons:

1. Signals you're too weak to win the nomination by yourself

2. Picking a running mate without the benefit of a thorough vetting process, would be disastrous if something disqualifying crops up

text: I don't oppose his candidacy. I'm not making endorsements, positive or negative. I'm skeptical of his prospects, and I explained my reasoning publicly. I think the hype got ahead of the reality. But the reality can always catch up!

text: ...I never said flatly that Beto couldn't win, & while I'm skeptical about his primary chances, he has plenty of time to prove himself & learn from past mistakes. If he does anything I consider worthy of positive note, I'll give him his due (as I did here https://www.politico.com/magazine/story/2018/12/24/democratic-2020-presidential-candidates-won-2018-223552 …)

text: I argued in print back in Nov. that the conventional case for Beto's presidential candidacy was deeply flawed, and the Senate path was a better bet. I stand by what I wrote, and nothing I've seen since makes me question it...

text: I can't think of any where that is literally the case. More common is for someone to be nominally named campaign manager, but the candidate doesn't properly relinquish control

text: Not the sort of thing that voters care about, but when the candidate is the campaign manager, problems are inevitable

text: This is getting attention for the slip suggesting he's running, but more notable is the explicit dig at the "new left" while laying claim to the "progressive" mantle.
author: billscher

text:
Again, I’m not the candidate! It’s the candidate’s job to explain his or her view on how government should be run, how financing works, etc. 

If you are proposing new programs without fully offset costs, fine! Then say so and explain your reasoning.
author: billscher

text: Don't know why you are directing this at me. Go tell Bernie to stop saying he's going to pay for his programs.
author: billscher

text: I'm not the candidate. As I said earlier, if Bernie wants to say, "I don't need to offset the costs because of MMT," he should do so and defend the position. So far, he has not done that, and instead has argued he will pay for his proposals.
author: billscher

text: It may well end up the case that the other candidates won’t be any better on specifics, most prefer to leave as much wiggle room as possible. But when you are proposing big ticket items, you’re gonna get asked “how?” Promising the moon is the easy part!
author: billscher

text:
His M4A bill came w/a white paper suggesting several financing options but wouldn’t commit to 1

He backs various taxes on the rich (politically easier than middle class hikes) but don’t fully cover the cost (see http://www.crfb.org/papers/adding-senator-sanderss-campaign-proposals-so-far …, this contends he lowballs the M4A cost)
author: billscher

text: Then Democrats would lose interest!
author: billscher

text: If things ever got that blue, Dems would have an Electoral College lock on the presidency and the appetite for NPV on the left would diminish ... though maybe then Republicans would get interested!
author: billscher

text: This is not happening without Republican support, which means it's not happening.
author: billscher

text: That's a novel approach to democracy
author: billscher

text:
If Bernie wants to go MMT, he should say so and defend it.

But he tends to say he is going to pay for his programs, then points to a specific type of tax on the wealthy, which wouldn't be enough to cover all the things he wants to do.
author: billscher

text: He should be more specific on pay-fors (unless he wants to argue in favor of deficit spending, but he typically doesn’t do that.)
author: billscher

text: Bernie takes more specific positions but does not always flesh out the details of those positions
author: billscher

text: “Gen Z is coming. We’re so angry.”
author: billscher

text: I think a lot of the early field erred in trying to approximate Bernie, which is essentially impossible, and has made it harder to distinguish themselves. Beto doesn't have that problem! But I think he has other ones.
author: billscher

text: I think folks are learning that you can't out-Bernie Bernie. But these shifts on Beto's part look like calculation, which conflicts with his brand.
author: billscher

text: I think people thought he was pulling off something special in Texas, when he was mainly benefiting from demographic changes, and so, they are learning the wrong lessons.
author: billscher

text: shoulda tried that in the Senate race! Now it looks like calculation, which conflicts with his brand.
author: billscher

text: ...so in my view, he's trying to upscale a flawed model. The fact that he has a lot of charisma is obscuring that. Now, he may well prove to be good prez candidate -Obama improved over the course of '07 - but everything I've seen since I wrote that piece doesn't make me hopeful
author: billscher

text: I think my skepticism comes from the different place than most others. As I argued back in Nov. https://www.politico.com/magazine/story/2018/11/20/beto-orourke-2020-president-campaign-analysis-222639 … the data doesn't support that he was a uniquely successful candidate in TX. He largely benefited from demographic shifts. The hype is ahead of the reality...

text: depends how you want to define "moderate." I mention the Energy Innovation and Carbon Dividend Act in the piece. Frankly, I wouldn't call that moderate! But it's getting that reputation in contrast to Green New Deal.

text:
Already getting complaints from Moderate Twitter (which exists!) that the House moderate ideas are out there, and idiot pundits like myself just don't report on them

I suspect any such overlooked ideas are smallball, but feel free to @ me with those ideas and I'll tweetstorm 'em
author: billscher

text: Please forgive the slightly simplified tweet. Yes, it's not quite literally zero. But even the occasional big idea is not remotely being adequately promoted (and fault there lies with both moderates and progressives, as noted in the piece.)
